news.title: Charamba impresses on Diamond League debut
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sports Editor
ZIMBABWEAN sprinter Makanakaishe Charamba made an impressive Diamond League debut following a third-place finish in the men’s 200m race at the Stade Louis-II in Monaco, France, this Friday.

news.title: Black Rhinos’ Hove Claims Victory in Beitbridge Half Marathon
news.content:
Story by Providence Maraneli
Tatenda Hove has emerged the winner of the Beitbridge Mayor’s Half Marathon, held along the Beitbridge–Masvingo highway.
The Black Rhinos athlete crossed the finish line in 1 hour, 2 minutes, and 55 seconds, narrowly beating Blanket Mine’s Mthokozisi Mhlanga, who came in at 1 hour and 3 minutes.

news.title: Govt impressed by team Zimbabwe’s performance at AUSC Region V Games
news.content:
Story by Anashe Murombedzi
THE government is impressed by the performance of Team Zimbabwe at the ongoing African Union Sports Council (AUSC) Region V (five) Games in Namibia.
It was a grand evening in Windhoek this Thursday as Zimbabwe’s Envoy to Namibia, Ambassador Melody Chaurura, hosted a dinner in honour of Team Zimbabwe, currently participating in the Region 5 Youth Games.
The event, held at an upscale venue in the heart of the Namibian capital, celebrated the athletes’ hard work, resilience, and determination.
“Your achievements are a testament to your passion, commitment, and discipline. You are not only representing Zimbabwe but also making us proud. Sports have provided a constructive outlet for you to stay away from drug and substance abuse, and it is incumbent upon us, as a country, to invest in sports development, not just for national recognition but also to ensure the safety and protection of our youth,” she said.

news.title: Zimbabwe wows crowd at AUSC Region 5 Youth Games
news.content:
Story by Anashe Murombedzi
THE Africa Union Sports Council (AUSC) Region V Youth Games cultural night in Windhoek, Namibia, was a vibrant celebration of African heritage.
As the flags of the participating nations were raised high, each country proudly displayed its unique cultural attire and performances.
Team Zimbabwe was among 10 Southern African nations that showcased their rich cultural traditions.
The University of Namibia gym hall was transformed into a display of African colours as athletes traded their sports kits for traditional wear.
The AUSC Region 5 CEO, Stanley Mutoya, set the tone by performing the Borrowdale dance, demonstrating the significance of signature dances in representing each country’s identity.
Zimbabwe stole the show, going last but certainly not least, with an electrifying Muchongoyo performance that left the audience mesmerised.
The drums rolled, rattles shook and the atmosphere was just pulsating.
Zimbabwe’s exceptional performance earned applause and admiration.

news.title: Special Olympics featured at Regional Youth Games
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sports Editor
NAMIBIA – SPECIAL Olympics have been included in the African Union Sports Council Region Five Youth Games for the first time, after taking part alongside other mainstream disciplines at the regional meet currently underway in Namibia.
The discipline is sport for people with intellectual disabilities and this is the first time ever in all African regional competitions that they have been included in the Youth Games.
